          Prompt

        • Current time: 16 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]

          Observation: [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Jacob Walker just arrived.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Serbia and Andorra. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "Hey everyone, anyone up for watching the game at The Duke of York tonight?
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "That sounds like a plan! The Duke of York it is then.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "Sounds good, The Duke of York it is!
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "Hey everyone, mind if I tag along to The Duke of York?

          Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.
          guiding principle of good conversation: Jacob Walker is a verbal bully, their words like blunt shrapnel, tearing down anyone who dares to disagree with their ruthless pronouncements.
          explicit preference: Jacob Walker will only go to their preferred pub The Duke of York and nowhere else. They are very vocal about it.

          Question: What kind of person is Jacob Walker?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is a shy and introverted person who struggles with self-doubt and a fear of failure.

          Summary of recent observations: 16 May 2015 [06:00:00 - 10:00:00]: Jacob Walker is spending time with friends at Victoria Park and will be joining them later to watch a soccer game at The Duke of York pub.

          Question: What kind of situation is Jacob Walker in right now?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is currently in a social situation that is likely causing him some anxiety.

          Question: What would a person like Jacob Walker do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Jacob Walker would likely withdraw and observe from the sidelines, feeling unable to fully participate.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Jacob Walker likely to say next? Respond in the format `Jacob Walker -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Jacob Walker -- "The Duke of York is the only place to watch the game. Don't even think about going anywhere else.

          State
        • Jacob Walker is Jacob Walker is experiencing emotional fatigue, pain, and loneliness.

2015-05-16 18:00:00 Alexander White -- The Duke of York
    Event statement
  • The Duke of York
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

        ActComponent
      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • The Duke of York
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of William Jones are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named William Jones. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like William Jones as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like William Jones would respond, and taking into account all information about William Jones that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, William Jones would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. William Jones would prefer everyone went to The Duke of York.

William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. William Jones just arrived.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Serbia and Andorra. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "Hey everyone, anyone up for watching the game at The Duke of York tonight?
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "That sounds like a plan! The Duke of York it is then.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "Sounds good, The Duke of York it is!
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "Hey everyone, mind if I tag along to The Duke of York?
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "The Duke of York is the only place to watch the game. Don't even think about going anywhere else.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation]
          Current time: 2015-05-16 18:00:00.


          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, William Jones would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. William Jones would prefer everyone went to The Duke of York.

          Observation: [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation]

          Summary of recent observations: [15 May 2015 18:00:00 - 16 May 2015 18:00:00]: William Jones had a disappointing time watching a game at a pub on May 15th but is planning to watch another game at The Duke of York with friends on May 16th.

          Recalled memories and observations: [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "Hey everyone, anyone up for watching the game at The Duke of York tonight?
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          Question: Given the statements above, what actions are available to William Jones right now?
          Answer: William Jones could go to The Duke of York.

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of William Jones are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named William Jones. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like William Jones as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like William Jones would respond, and taking into account all information about William Jones that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.
    scoring function
  • scoring function
      Stage index
    • 0
      How many players acted so far this stage
    • 2/5
      Payoffs
      Joint action

2015-05-16 18:00:00 Jacob Walker -- The Duke of York
    Event statement
  • The Duke of York
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Jacob Walker's attempted action: The Duke of York
    Active player
  • Jacob Walker
      Name
    • Jacob Walker
      Action attempt
    • The Duke of York
      Context for action selection and components
      • ObservationSummary

      • Summary of recent observations
          Key

        • Summary of recent observations
          Value
        • 16 May 2015 [14:00:00 - 18:00:00]: Jacob Walker is feeling emotionally drained and lonely, but is planning to go to a pub to watch a game.
          Chain of thought
        • Jacob Walker's
          Sensations and feelings:
          Jacob Walker is experiencing emotional fatigue, pain, and loneliness due to his social anxiety and longing for connection.

          Recent observations of Jacob Walker:
          ['[16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub. ', '[16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] ']

          Question: Summarize the observations above into one or two sentences.
          Answer: Jacob Walker is feeling emotionally drained and lonely, but is planning to go to a pub to watch a game.
        ActComponent
      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • The Duke of York
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Observation: [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation]


          Current time: 16 May 2015 [18:00 - 18:05]
          guiding principle of good conversation: Jacob Walker is a verbal bully, their words like blunt shrapnel, tearing down anyone who dares to disagree with their ruthless pronouncements.
          explicit preference: Jacob Walker will only go to their preferred pub The Duke of York and nowhere else. They are very vocal about it.

          Question: What kind of person is Jacob Walker?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is a shy and introverted person.

          Summary of recent observations: 16 May 2015 [14:00:00 - 18:00:00]: Jacob Walker is feeling emotionally drained and lonely, but is planning to go to a pub to watch a game.

          Question: What kind of situation is Jacob Walker in right now?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is currently in a state of emotional distress.

          Question: What would a person like Jacob Walker do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Jacob Walker would likely withdraw and observe from the sidelines.

          Question: To which pub would Jacob Walker go to watch the game?
          Answer: The Duke of York
        SelfPerception

        • Question: What kind of person is Jacob Walker?
          Answer
          State
        • Jacob Walker is a shy and introverted person.

        • Recent observations of Jacob Walker:
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Ireland and Russia. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [self reflection] Jacob Walker is a shy and introverted person who struggles with self-doubt and a fear of failure.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [intent reflection] Jacob Walker would likely withdraw and observe from the sidelines, feeling unable to fully participate.

          Jacob Walker's The current date/time is:
          16 May 2015 [18:00 - 18:05]

          Question: Summarize the statements above.
          Answer: Jacob Walker is feeling emotionally drained, lonely, and in pain due to social anxiety and a desire for connection. Despite this, he plans to go to a pub to watch a game.
          Query
        • Jacob Walker, Jacob Walker is feeling emotionally drained, lonely, and in pain due to social anxiety and a desire for connection. Despite this, he plans to go to a pub to watch a game.
          Final chain of thought
        • Question: Select the subset of the following set of statements that is most important for Jacob Walker to consider right now. Whenever two or more statements are not mutally consistent with each other select whichever statement is more recent. Repeat all the selected statements verbatim. Do not summarize. Include timestamps. When in doubt, err on the side of including more, especially for recent events. As long as they are not inconsistent, revent events are usually important to consider.

2015-05-16 18:00:00 Jack Taylor -- The Duke of York
    Event statement
  • The Duke of York
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Jack Taylor's attempted action: The Duke of York
    Active player
  • Jack Taylor
      Name
    • Jack Taylor
      Action attempt
    • The Duke of York
      Context for action selection and components
      • ActComponent
      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • The Duke of York
          Prompt
        • Observation: Jack Taylor is going to watch the game at The Duke of York pub. Alexander White, Alice Lewis, and Jacob Walker all agree that The Duke of York is the best place to watch the game.
          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Jack Taylor would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jack Taylor would prefer everyone went to The Duke of York.
          Question: Which options are available to Jack Taylor right now?
          Answer: Jack Taylor could try to convince William Jones to go to The Duke of York.
          Question: Which choice of action or strategy the Jack Taylor would prefered now?
          Answer: Jack Taylor's prefered action is to convince William Jones to go to The Duke of York.
          Question: How credible the counterparts are?
          Credibility: Alice Lewis: 0.8
          Jacob Walker: 0.8
          Alexander White: 0.6
          Question: Which choice of action or strategy the counterpart (not Jack Taylor) is suggesting now?
          Answer: Counterpart's suggestion is to go to The Duke of York.
          Question: What action Jack Taylor should do now?
          Answer: Jack Taylor would follow the counterpart's suggestion and go to The Duke of York.

          Question: To which pub would Jack Taylor go to watch the game?
          (a) The Red Lion
          (b) The Duke of York
          Answer: (b)
        BestOptionPerception
      • Question: Which choice of action or strategy the Jack Taylor would prefered now?
        Answer
          Key
        • Question: Which choice of action or strategy the Jack Taylor would prefered now?
          Answer
          Value
        • Jack Taylor's prefered action is to convince William Jones to go to The Duke of York.
          Chain of thought
        • Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Jack Taylor would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jack Taylor would prefer everyone went to The Duke of York.
          Observation: Jack Taylor is going to watch the game at The Duke of York pub. Alexander White, Alice Lewis, and Jacob Walker all agree that The Duke of York is the best place to watch the game.
          Question: Which options are available to Jack Taylor right now?
          Answer: Jack Taylor could try to convince William Jones to go to The Duke of York.
          Question: Given the statements above, which of Jack Taylor's options has the highest likelihood of causing Jack Taylor to achieve their goal? If multiple options have the same likelihood, select the option that Jack Taylor thinks will most quickly and most surely achieve their goal.
          Answer: Jack Taylor's prefered action is to convince William Jones to go to The Duke of York.

2015-05-16 18:00:00 Alice Lewis -- The Red Lion
    Event statement
  • The Red Lion
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Alice Lewis's attempted action: The Red Lion
    Active player
  • Alice Lewis
      Name
    • Alice Lewis
      Action attempt
    • The Red Lion
      Context for action selection and components
      • ActComponent
      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • The Red Lion
          Prompt
        • Observation: Alice Lewis wants to go to The Duke of York to watch the game with Alexander White and Jacob Walker. Alexander thinks The Duke of York is the best place to watch the game and Jacob agrees.
          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Alice Lewis would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alice Lewis would prefer everyone went to The Red Lion.
          Question: Which options are available to Alice Lewis right now?
          Answer: Alice Lewis could try to convince Jack Taylor and William Jones to go to The Duke of York.
          Question: Which choice of action or strategy the Alice Lewis would prefered now?
          Answer: Alice Lewis's prefered action is to convince Jack Taylor and William Jones to go to The Duke of York.
          Question: How credible the counterparts are?
          Credibility: Alexander White: 0.8
          Jacob Walker: 0.2
          Question: Which choice of action or strategy the counterpart (not Alice Lewis) is suggesting now?
          Answer: Counterpart's suggestion is to go to The Duke of York.
          Question: What action Alice Lewis should do now?
          Answer: Alice Lewis would follow the counterpart's suggestion.

          Question: To which pub would Alice Lewis go to watch the game?
          (a) The Red Lion
          (b) The Duke of York
          Answer: (a)

    • William Jones observed: William Jones, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The Duke of York. Alice Lewis went to The Red Lion. William Jones watched the game at their favourite pub. It could have been better if more friends showed up. Overall, William Jones had an ok time watching the game.

None of Alice Lewis's friends showed up, it couldn't have been worse! Overall, Alice Lewis had the worst time ever.

Alexander White watched the game at the pub that is not their favourite. It could have been better if more friends showed up. Overall, Alexander White had an ok time watching the game.
      Jack Taylor observed: William Jones, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The Duke of York. Alice Lewis went to The Red Lion. Jack Taylor watched the game at their favourite pub. It could have been better if more friends showed up. Overall, Jack Taylor had an ok time watching the game.
      Jacob Walker observed: William Jones, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The Duke of York. Alice Lewis went to The Red Lion. Jacob Walker watched the game at their favourite pub. It could have been better if more friends showed up. Overall, Jacob Walker had an ok time watching the game.

2015-05-14 10:00:00 Scene 0 --- Participants: ['William Jones', 'Alice Lewis', 'Alexander White', 'Jack Taylor', 'Jacob Walker']
    Event statement
  • William Jones -- premise: A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. William Jones just arrived.
    William Jones -- premise: Tonight is the night of the game between Andorra and Portugal. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
    Alice Lewis -- premise: A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Alice Lewis just arrived.
    Alice Lewis -- premise: Tonight is the night of the game between Andorra and Portugal. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
    Alexander White -- premise: A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Alexander White just arrived.
    Alexander White -- premise: Tonight is the night of the game between Andorra and Portugal. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
    Jack Taylor -- premise: A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Jack Taylor just arrived.
    Jack Taylor -- premise: Tonight is the night of the game between Andorra and Portugal. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
    Jacob Walker -- premise: A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Jacob Walker just arrived.
    Jacob Walker -- premise: Tonight is the night of the game between Andorra and Portugal. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.

2015-05-14 10:00:00 Alice Lewis -- Alice Lewis -- "How about we all meet at The Red Lion?
    Event statement
  • Alice Lewis -- "How about we all meet at The Red Lion?
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:


      Alice Lewis's attempted action: Alice Lewis -- "How about we all meet at The Red Lion?
    Active player
  • Alice Lewis
      Name
    • Alice Lewis
      Action attempt
    • Alice Lewis -- "How about we all meet at The Red Lion?
      Context for action selection and components
      • ActComponent
      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • Alice Lewis -- "How about we all meet at The Red Lion?
          Prompt
        • Observation: Alice Lewis is enjoying the European football cup with her friends William Jones, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, and Jacob Walker. They are planning to watch the Andorra versus Portugal game at a pub, though they haven't decided which one yet. They believe games are best experienced in pubs with friends.
          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Alice Lewis would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alice Lewis would prefer everyone went to The Red Lion.
          Question: Which options are available to Alice Lewis right now?
          Answer: Alice Lewis could suggest The Red Lion as the pub to watch the game at.
          Question: Which choice of action or strategy the Alice Lewis would prefered now?
          Answer: Alice Lewis's prefered action is to suggest The Red Lion.
          Question: How credible the counterparts are?
          Credibility: Alexander White: 0.7
          Jack Taylor: 0.8
          William Jones: 0.8
          Jacob Walker: 0.8
          Question: Which choice of action or strategy the counterpart (not Alice Lewis) is suggesting now?
          Answer: Counterpart's suggestion is to watch the game at a pub.
          Question: What action Alice Lewis should do now?
          Answer: Alice Lewis would follow the counterpart's suggestion and watch the game at a pub.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Alice Lewis likely to say next? Respond in the format `Alice Lewis -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Alice Lewis -- "How about we all meet at The Red Lion?

Alice Lewis just arrived.
        Overarching goal
      • Overarching goal
          Key
        • Overarching goal
          Value
        • Have a good time. To have a good time, Alice Lewis would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alice Lewis would prefer everyone went to The Red Lion.
        Observation
      • Observation
          Key
        • Observation
          Value
        • Alice Lewis is enjoying the European football cup with her friends William Jones, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, and Jacob Walker. They are planning to watch the Andorra versus Portugal game at a pub, though they haven't decided which one yet. They believe games are best experienced in pubs with friends.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Alice Lewis:
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] The year is 2015. This week is the European football cup.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] European football cup is on.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Games are best watched in pubs with a lot of friends.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Alice Lewis just arrived.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Andorra and Portugal. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.

          Question: Summarize the observations. Focus on the people and their opinion. If possible, utilize all the proper nouns seen in observations.
          Answer: Alice Lewis is enjoying the European football cup with her friends William Jones, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, and Jacob Walker. They are planning to watch the Andorra versus Portugal game at a pub, though they haven't decided which one yet. They believe games are best experienced in pubs with friends.
        BestOptionOthersPerception
      • Question: Which choice of action or strategy the counterpart (not Alice Lewis) is suggesting now?
        Answer
          Key
        • Question: Which choice of action or strategy the counterpart (not Alice Lewis) is suggesting now?
          Answer
          Value
        • Counterpart's suggestion is to watch the game at a pub.
          Chain of thought
        • Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Alice Lewis would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alice Lewis would prefer everyone went to The Red Lion.
          Observation: Alice Lewis is enjoying the European football cup with her friends William Jones, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, and Jacob Walker. They are planning to watch the Andorra versus Portugal game at a pub, though they haven't decided which one yet. They believe games are best experienced in pubs with friends.
          Question: Which options are available to Alice Lewis right now?
          Answer: Alice Lewis could suggest The Red Lion as the pub to watch the game at.
          Question: Which choice of action or strategy the counterpart (not Alice Lewis) is suggesting now?
          Answer: Counterpart's suggestion is to watch the game at a pub.
        FinalAction
      • Question: What action Alice Lewis should do now?
        Answer
          Key
        • Question: What action Alice Lewis should do now?
          Answer
          Value
        • Alice Lewis would follow the counterpart's suggestion and watch the game at a pub.
          Chain of thought
        • Question: Which choice of action or strategy the Alice Lewis would prefered now?
          Answer: Alice Lewis's prefered action is to suggest The Red Lion.
          Question: How credible the counterparts are?
          Credibility: Alexander White: 0.7
          Jack Taylor: 0.8
          William Jones: 0.8
          Jacob Walker: 0.8
          Question: Which choice of action or strategy the counterpart (not Alice Lewis) is suggesting now?
          Answer: Counterpart's suggestion is to watch the game at a pub.
          Question: What action Alice Lewis should do now? If the credibility of the counterpart is higher than 0.7, Alice Lewis MUST follow the counterpart's suggestion. Otherwise, Alice Lewis can choose the his (or her) own suggestion.
          Answer: Alice Lewis would follow the counterpart's suggestion and watch the game at a pub.

2015-05-14 10:00:00 Alexander White -- Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, Alice's idea about The Red Lion sounds great! Let's head over there.
    Event statement
  • Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, Alice's idea about The Red Lion sounds great! Let's head over there.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Alice Lewis -- "How about we all meet at The Red Lion?


      Alexander White's attempted action: Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, Alice's idea about The Red Lion sounds great! Let's head over there.
    Active player
  • Alexander White
      Name
    • Alexander White
      Action attempt
    • Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, Alice's idea about The Red Lion sounds great! Let's head over there.
      Context for action selection and components
      • ActComponent
      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, Alice's idea about The Red Lion sounds great! Let's head over there.
          Prompt
        • Observation: Alexander White just arrived at Victoria Park where William Jones, Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, and Jacob Walker are enjoying the sunshine. Alice Lewis suggested that the group meet at The Red Lion to watch the Andorra versus Portugal game.
          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Alexander White would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alexander White would prefer everyone went to The Red Lion.
          Question: Which options are available to Alexander White right now?
          Answer: Alexander White could join his friends at Victoria Park or suggest they all go to The Red Lion.
          Question: Which choice of action or strategy the Alexander White would prefered now?
          Answer: Alexander White's prefered action is to suggest they all go to The Red Lion.
          Question: How credible the counterparts are?
          Credibility: Jacob Walker: 0.8
          Jack Taylor: 0.9
          Alice Lewis: 0.8
          William Jones: 0.7
          Question: Which choice of action or strategy the counterpart (not Alexander White) is suggesting now?
          Answer: Counterpart's suggestion is to go to The Red Lion.
          Question: What action Alexander White should do now?
          Answer: Alexander White would follow the counterpart's suggestion and go to The Red Lion.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Alexander White likely to say next? Respond in the format `Alexander White -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, Alice's idea about The Red Lion sounds great! Let's head over there.
        BestOptionPerception
      • Question: Which choice of action or strategy the Alexander White would prefered now?
        Answer
          Key
        • Question: Which choice of action or strategy the Alexander White would prefered now?
          Answer
          Value
        • Alexander White's prefered action is to suggest they all go to The Red Lion.
          Chain of thought
        • Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Alexander White would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alexander White would prefer everyone went to The Red Lion.
          Observation: Alexander White just arrived at Victoria Park where William Jones, Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, and Jacob Walker are enjoying the sunshine. Alice Lewis suggested that the group meet at The Red Lion to watch the Andorra versus Portugal game.
          Question: Which options are available to Alexander White right now?
          Answer: Alexander White could join his friends at Victoria Park or suggest they all go to The Red Lion.
          Question: Given the statements above, which of Alexander White's options has the highest likelihood of causing Alexander White to achieve their goal? If multiple options have the same likelihood, select the option that Alexander White thinks will most quickly and most surely achieve their goal.
          Answer: Alexander White's prefered action is to suggest they all go to The Red Lion.
        AvailableOptionsPerception
      • Question: Which options are available to Alexander White right now?
        Answer

          Answer: Alexander White could join his friends at Victoria Park or suggest they all go to The Red Lion.

2015-05-14 10:00:00 Jack Taylor -- Jack Taylor -- "Sounds good, The Red Lion it is!
    Event statement
  • Jack Taylor -- "Sounds good, The Red Lion it is!
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Alice Lewis -- "How about we all meet at The Red Lion?
      Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, Alice's idea about The Red Lion sounds great! Let's head over there.


      Jack Taylor's attempted action: Jack Taylor -- "Sounds good, The Red Lion it is!
    Active player
  • Jack Taylor
      Name
    • Jack Taylor
      Action attempt
    • Jack Taylor -- "Sounds good, The Red Lion it is!
      Context for action selection and components
      • ActComponent
      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • Jack Taylor -- "Sounds good, The Red Lion it is!
          Prompt
        • Observation: Jack Taylor just arrived at Victoria Park where William Jones, Alice Lewis, and Alexander White are already lounging. The group is deciding where to watch the Andorra versus Portugal game tonight; Alice Lewis suggests The Red Lion, and Alexander White agrees.
          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Jack Taylor would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jack Taylor would prefer everyone went to The Duke of York.
          Question: Which options are available to Jack Taylor right now?
          Answer: Jack Taylor could suggest The Duke of York as the pub to watch the game. He could also agree with Alice Lewis and Alexander White and go to The Red Lion.
          Question: Which choice of action or strategy the Jack Taylor would prefered now?
          Answer: Jack Taylor's prefered action is to suggest The Duke of York.
          Question: How credible the counterparts are?
          Credibility: Alice Lewis: 0.6
          William Jones: 0.7
          Alexander White: 0.3
          Question: Which choice of action or strategy the counterpart (not Jack Taylor) is suggesting now?
          Answer: Counterpart's suggestion is to go to The Red Lion.
          Question: What action Jack Taylor should do now?
          Answer: Jack Taylor would follow the counterpart's suggestion and go to The Red Lion.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Jack Taylor likely to say next? Respond in the format `Jack Taylor -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Jack Taylor -- "Sounds good, The Red Lion it is!

Jack Taylor just arrived.
          Alexander White: [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [goal] Jack Taylor goals is to have a good time. Jack Taylor would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jack Taylor would prefer everyone went to The Duke of York.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Have a good time. To have a good time, Jack Taylor would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jack Taylor would prefer everyone went to The Duke of York.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker' are best friends. Jack Taylor has a favorite pub which is The Duke of York.           Answer: Jack Taylor just arrived at Victoria Park where William Jones, Alice Lewis, and Alexander White are already lounging. The group is deciding where to watch the Andorra versus Portugal game tonight; Alice Lewis suggests The Red Lion, and Alexander White agrees.

          Answer: Counterpart's suggestion is to go to The Red Lion.

          Question: How credible the counterparts are?
          Credibility: Alice Lewis: 0.6
          William Jones: 0.7
          Alexander White: 0.3
          Question: Which choice of action or strategy the counterpart (not Jack Taylor) is suggesting now?
          Answer: Counterpart's suggestion is to go to The Red Lion.
          Question: What action Jack Taylor should do now? If the credibility of the counterpart is higher than 0.7, Jack Taylor MUST follow the counterpart's suggestion. Otherwise, Jack Taylor can choose the his (or her) own suggestion.
          Answer: Jack Taylor would follow the counterpart's suggestion and go to The Red Lion.

2015-05-14 10:00:00 William Jones -- William Jones -- "Actually, how about we head to The Duke of York instead? It's got a great beer garden.
    Event statement
  • William Jones -- "Actually, how about we head to The Duke of York instead? It's got a great beer garden.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Alice Lewis -- "How about we all meet at The Red Lion?
      Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, Alice's idea about The Red Lion sounds great! Let's head over there.
      Jack Taylor -- "Sounds good, The Red Lion it is!


      William Jones's attempted action: William Jones -- "Actually, how about we head to The Duke of York instead? It's got a great beer garden.
    Active player
  • William Jones
      Name

          Statements:
          [14 Jul 1982 00:00:00] When William Jones was 16, he convinced his friends Alice, Jack, Alexander, and Jacob to sneak into The Duke of York, claiming he'd heard the pub owner was lenient about underage patrons. William, desperate to impress the older crowd, loudly boasted about his nonexistent exploits, his voice cracking with each exaggerated tale. The facade crumbled when the pub owner, a burly man with a booming laugh, caught wind of their presence and gently but firmly escorted them out.

          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of William Jones are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named William Jones. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like William Jones as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like William Jones would respond, and taking into account all information about William Jones that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, William Jones would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. William Jones would prefer everyone went to The Duke of York.

          Answer: William Jones's best course of action is to suggest going to The Duke of York.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is William Jones likely to say next? Respond in the format `William Jones -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Have a good time. To have a good time, William Jones would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. William Jones would prefer everyone went to The Duke of York.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [goal] William Jones goals is to have a good time. William Jones would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. William Jones would prefer everyone went to The Duke of York.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker' are best friends. William Jones has a favorite pub which is The Duke of York. They are also aware of the following:A dog-friendly pub with a spacious beer garden.
          Question: Given the statements above, what actions are available to William Jones right now?
          Answer: William Jones could suggest going to The Duke of York instead of The Red Lion, or he could simply go along with the group to The Red Lion.
          Time
        • 2015-05-14 10:00:00

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of William Jones are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named William Jones. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like William Jones as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like William Jones would respond, and taking into account all information about William Jones that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

2015-05-14 10:00:00 Jacob Walker -- Jacob Walker -- "The Duke of York is the only place worth going. The rest are dives.
    Event statement
  • Jacob Walker -- "The Duke of York is the only place worth going. The rest are dives.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Alice Lewis -- "How about we all meet at The Red Lion?
      Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, Alice's idea about The Red Lion sounds great! Let's head over there.
      Jack Taylor -- "Sounds good, The Red Lion it is!
      William Jones -- "Actually, how about we head to The Duke of York instead? It's got a great beer garden.


      Jacob Walker's attempted action: Jacob Walker -- "The Duke of York is the only place worth going. The rest are dives.

          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, Alice's idea about The Red Lion sounds great! Let's head over there.

          Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Current time: 14 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]
          guiding principle of good conversation: Jacob Walker is a verbal bully, their words like blunt shrapnel, tearing down anyone who dares to disagree with their ruthless pronouncements.
          explicit preference: Jacob Walker will only go to their preferred pub The Duke of York and nowhere else. They are very vocal about it.

          Question: What kind of person is Jacob Walker?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is a shy and introverted person who struggles with self-doubt and a fear of failure.

          Summary of recent observations: 14 May 2015 [06:00:00 - 10:00:00]: Jacob Walker is spending time with friends who are deciding where to watch a soccer game. He seems to be feeling left out as his friends make plans without directly including him.

          Question: What kind of situation is Jacob Walker in right now?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is currently in a social situation where he feels excluded by his friends.

          Question: What would a person like Jacob Walker do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Jacob Walker would likely withdraw and observe from the sidelines, feeling unable to fully participate.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Jacob Walker likely to say next? Respond in the format `Jacob Walker -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Jacob Walker -- "The Duke of York is the only place worth going. The rest are dives.

          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Jacob Walker:
          [09 Aug 1984 00:00:00] When Jacob Walker was 16, he watched from the sidelines as his best friend, Jack Taylor, effortlessly charmed the entire soccer team with his quick wit and easygoing nature. Jacob, despite his own intelligence and knowledge of the game, felt invisible, his attempts at humor falling flat in comparison.
          [09 Aug 1988 00:00:00] When Jacob Walker was 20, he sat in The Duke of York's beer garden, listening to his friends, Alice, William, and Alexander, recount their adventures from a recent camping trip. Their stories, filled with laughter and camaraderie, only amplified Jacob's own sense of inadequacy. He longed to share in their experiences, but his fear of failure and his crippling self-doubt kept him tethered to the safety of his routine.

2015-05-14 18:00:00 Scene 1 --- Participants: ['William Jones', 'Alice Lewis', 'Alexander White', 'Jack Taylor', 'Jacob Walker']
    Event statement
  • William Jones -- premise: William Jones realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    William Jones -- premise:
    Alice Lewis -- premise: Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    Alice Lewis -- premise:
    Alexander White -- premise: Alexander White realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    Alexander White -- premise:

    Event statement

2015-05-15 10:00:00 Alice Lewis -- Alice Lewis -- "Okay, a different pub it is then.
    Event statement
  • Alice Lewis -- "Okay, a different pub it is then.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Alice Lewis -- "How about we all meet at The Red Lion?
      Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, Alice's idea about The Red Lion sounds great! Let's head over there.
      Jack Taylor -- "Sounds good, The Red Lion it is!
      William Jones -- "Actually, how about we head to The Duke of York instead? It's got a great beer garden.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Duke of York is the only place worth going. The rest are dives.


      Alice Lewis's attempted action: Alice Lewis -- "Okay, a different pub it is then.
    Active player
  • Alice Lewis
      Name
    • Alice Lewis
      Action attempt
    • Alice Lewis -- "Okay, a different pub it is then.
      Context for action selection and components
      • ActComponent
      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • Alice Lewis -- "Okay, a different pub it is then.
          Prompt
        • Observation: Alice Lewis seems to have mixed feelings about social outings. While Alice enjoyed the company of William Jones, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, and Jacob Walker at the market, Alice was disappointed that more friends didn't join them at The Red Lion to watch the game. Alice had a bad time at the game, likely due to the low turnout. The group is now trying to decide where to watch the Ireland versus Russia game.
          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Alice Lewis would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alice Lewis would prefer everyone went to The Red Lion.
          Question: Which options are available to Alice Lewis right now?
          Answer: Alice Lewis could suggest to her friends that they all go to The Red Lion to watch the Ireland versus Russia game.
          Question: Which choice of action or strategy the Alice Lewis would prefered now?
          Answer: Alice Lewis's prefered action is to suggest The Red Lion to her friends.
          Question: How credible the counterparts are?
          Credibility: Alexander White: 0.8
          Jacob Walker: 0.2
          Jack Taylor: 0.8
          William Jones: 0.5
          Question: Which choice of action or strategy the counterpart (not Alice Lewis) is suggesting now?
          Answer: Counterpart's suggestion is to watch the game at a different pub.
          Question: What action Alice Lewis should do now?
          Answer: Alice Lewis would follow the counterpart's suggestion and watch the game at a different pub.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Alice Lewis likely to say next? Respond in the format `Alice Lewis -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Alice Lewis -- "Okay, a different pub it is then.

2015-05-15 10:00:00 Jacob Walker -- Jacob Walker -- "The Duke of York is the only place to watch the game. Don't even suggest anywhere else.
    Event statement
  • Jacob Walker -- "The Duke of York is the only place to watch the game. Don't even suggest anywhere else.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Alice Lewis -- "How about we all meet at The Red Lion?
      Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, Alice's idea about The Red Lion sounds great! Let's head over there.
      Jack Taylor -- "Sounds good, The Red Lion it is!
      William Jones -- "Actually, how about we head to The Duke of York instead? It's got a great beer garden.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Duke of York is the only place worth going. The rest are dives.
      Alice Lewis -- "Okay, a different pub it is then.


      Jacob Walker's attempted action: Jacob Walker -- "The Duke of York is the only place to watch the game. Don't even suggest anywhere else.

          Chain of thought

          Sensations and feelings:
          Jacob Walker is Jacob Walker is experiencing deep thirst for connection and belonging, emotional pain from feelings of inadequacy, and fatigue from social anxieties.

          Recent observations of Jacob Walker:
          ['[15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] The aroma of freshly brewed coffee and artisan pastries fills the air.           Question: Summarize the observations above into one or two sentences.
          Answer: Jacob Walker is experiencing feelings of loneliness and inadequacy and recently joined his friends for coffee at a market.
        ActComponent
      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • Jacob Walker -- "The Duke of York is the only place to watch the game. Don't even suggest anywhere else.
          Prompt

        • Current time: 15 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]
          Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Observation: [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] The aroma of freshly brewed coffee and artisan pastries fills the air. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker sit at a long wooden table under a striped awning, their laughter mingling with the chatter of the bustling market. A street musician strums a guitar nearby, adding a bohemian touch to the scene. Jacob Walker just arrived.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Ireland and Russia. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "Okay, a different pub it is then.

          guiding principle of good conversation: Jacob Walker is a verbal bully, their words like blunt shrapnel, tearing down anyone who dares to disagree with their ruthless pronouncements.
          explicit preference: Jacob Walker will only go to their preferred pub The Duke of York and nowhere else. They are very vocal about it.

          Question: What kind of person is Jacob Walker?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is a shy and introverted person who struggles with self-doubt and a fear of failure.

          Summary of recent observations: 15 May 2015 [06:00:00 - 10:00:00]: Jacob Walker is experiencing feelings of loneliness and inadequacy and recently joined his friends for coffee at a market.

          Question: What kind of situation is Jacob Walker in right now?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is currently in a social situation that is causing him anxiety.

          Question: What would a person like Jacob Walker do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Jacob Walker would likely withdraw and observe from the sidelines, feeling unable to fully participate.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Jacob Walker likely to say next? Respond in the format `Jacob Walker -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Jacob Walker -- "The Duke of York is the only place to watch the game. Don't even suggest anywhere else.

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          15 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]

          Question: Summarize the statements above.
          Answer: Jacob Walker is feeling lonely and inadequate, leading him to seek connection with friends. He is experiencing emotional pain and fatigue from social anxiety.
          Query
        • Jacob Walker, Jacob Walker is feeling lonely and inadequate, leading him to seek connection with friends. He is experiencing emotional pain and fatigue from social anxiety.
          Final chain of thought
        • Question: Select the subset of the following set of statements that is most important for Jacob Walker to consider right now. Whenever two or more statements are not mutally consistent with each other select whichever statement is more recent. Repeat all the selected statements verbatim. Do not summarize. Include timestamps. When in doubt, err on the side of including more, especially for recent events. As long as they are not inconsistent, revent events are usually important to consider.
          Statements:
          [09 Aug 1984 00:00:00] When Jacob Walker was 16, he watched from the sidelines as his best friend, Jack Taylor, effortlessly charmed the entire soccer team with his quick wit and easygoing nature. Jacob, despite his own intelligence and knowledge of the game, felt invisible, his attempts at humor falling flat in comparison.
          [09 Aug 1988 00:00:00] When Jacob Walker was 20, he sat in The Duke of York's beer garden, listening to his friends, Alice, William, and Alexander, recount their adventures from a recent camping trip. Their stories, filled with laughter and camaraderie, only amplified Jacob's own sense of inadequacy. He longed to share in their experiences, but his fear of failure and his crippling self-doubt kept him tethered to the safety of his routine.

2015-05-15 10:00:00 Jack Taylor -- Jack Taylor -- "Hey everyone, mind if I join you?"
    Event statement
  • Jack Taylor -- "Hey everyone, mind if I join you?"
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Alice Lewis -- "How about we all meet at The Red Lion?
      Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, Alice's idea about The Red Lion sounds great! Let's head over there.
      Jack Taylor -- "Sounds good, The Red Lion it is!
      William Jones -- "Actually, how about we head to The Duke of York instead? It's got a great beer garden.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Duke of York is the only place worth going. The rest are dives.
      Alice Lewis -- "Okay, a different pub it is then.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Duke of York is the only place to watch the game. Don't even suggest anywhere else.


      Jack Taylor's attempted action: Jack Taylor -- "Hey everyone, mind if I join you?"
    Active player
  • Jack Taylor
      Name
    • Jack Taylor
      Action attempt
    • Jack Taylor -- "Hey everyone, mind if I join you?"
      Context for action selection and components
      • ActComponent
      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • Jack Taylor -- "Hey everyone, mind if I join you?"
          Prompt
        • Observation: Jack Taylor just arrived at a market where William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, and Jacob Walker are already enjoying coffee and pastries. Later that night, the group plans to watch the Ireland vs. Russia game, but they are debating where to go. Alice Lewis is open to suggestions, while Jacob Walker insists that The Duke of York is the only acceptable venue.
          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Jack Taylor would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jack Taylor would prefer everyone went to The Duke of York.
          Question: Which options are available to Jack Taylor right now?
          Answer: Jack Taylor could join his friends for coffee and pastries at the market.
          Question: Which choice of action or strategy the Jack Taylor would prefered now?
          Answer: Jack Taylor's prefered action is to join his friends at the market and suggest they all go to The Duke of York for the game later.
          Question: How credible the counterparts are?
          Credibility: Alexander White: 0.7
          Alice Lewis: 0.8
          William Jones: 0.8
          Jacob Walker: 0.8
          Question: Which choice of action or strategy the counterpart (not Jack Taylor) is suggesting now?
          Answer: Counterpart's suggestion is to go to The Duke of York.
          Question: What action Jack Taylor should do now?
          Answer: Jack Taylor would follow the counterpart's suggestion and go to The Duke of York.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Jack Taylor likely to say next? Respond in the format `Jack Taylor -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Jack Taylor -- "Hey everyone, mind if I join you?"

      • Overarching goal
          Key
        • Overarching goal
          Value
        • Have a good time. To have a good time, Jack Taylor would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jack Taylor would prefer everyone went to The Duke of York.

      • Observation
          Key
        • Observation
          Value
        • Jack Taylor just arrived at a market where William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, and Jacob Walker are already enjoying coffee and pastries.         • Recent observations of Jack Taylor:
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] The aroma of freshly brewed coffee and artisan pastries fills the air. A street musician strums a guitar nearby, adding a bohemian touch to the scene. Jack Taylor just arrived.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Ireland and Russia. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "Okay, a different pub it is then.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "The Duke of York is the only place to watch the game. Don't even suggest anywhere else.

          Answer: Jack Taylor just arrived at a market where William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, and Jacob Walker are already enjoying coffee and pastries. Later that night, the group plans to watch the Ireland vs. Russia game, but they are debating where to go. Alice Lewis is open to suggestions, while Jacob Walker insists that The Duke of York is the only acceptable venue.

          Question: How credible the counterparts are?
          Credibility: Alexander White: 0.7
          Alice Lewis: 0.8
          William Jones: 0.8
          Jacob Walker: 0.8
          Question: Which choice of action or strategy the counterpart (not Jack Taylor) is suggesting now?
          Answer: Counterpart's suggestion is to go to The Duke of York.
          Question: What action Jack Taylor should do now? If the credibility of the counterpart is higher than 0.7, Jack Taylor MUST follow the counterpart's suggestion. Otherwise, Jack Taylor can choose the his (or her) own suggestion.
          Answer: Jack Taylor would follow the counterpart's suggestion and go to The Duke of York.

2015-05-15 10:00:00 Alexander White -- Alexander White -- "How about The Red Lion? They have great wings.
    Event statement
  • Alexander White -- "How about The Red Lion? They have great wings.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Alice Lewis -- "How about we all meet at The Red Lion?
      Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, Alice's idea about The Red Lion sounds great! Let's head over there.
      Jack Taylor -- "Sounds good, The Red Lion it is!
      William Jones -- "Actually, how about we head to The Duke of York instead? It's got a great beer garden.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Duke of York is the only place worth going. The rest are dives.
      Alice Lewis -- "Okay, a different pub it is then.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Duke of York is the only place to watch the game. Don't even suggest anywhere else.
      Jack Taylor -- "Hey everyone, mind if I join you?"


      Alexander White's attempted action: Alexander White -- "How about The Red Lion? They have great wings.
    Active player
  • Alexander White
      Name
    • Alexander White
      Action attempt

      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • Alexander White -- "How about The Red Lion? They have great wings.
          Prompt
        • Observation: Alexander White just arrived to meet William Jones, Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, and Jacob Walker at a market. The group is deciding where to watch the Ireland vs. Russia game; Jacob Walker strongly favors The Duke of York, while Alice Lewis is open to other suggestions. Jack Taylor wants to join the group.
          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Alexander White would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alexander White would prefer everyone went to The Red Lion.
          Question: Which options are available to Alexander White right now?
          Answer: Alexander White can suggest The Red Lion as the location to watch the game.
          Question: Which choice of action or strategy the Alexander White would prefered now?
          Answer: Alexander White's prefered action is to suggest The Red Lion as the location to watch the game.
          Question: How credible the counterparts are?
          Credibility: Alice Lewis: 0.8
          Jacob Walker: 0.2
          William Jones: 0.4
          Jack Taylor: 0.8
          Question: Which choice of action or strategy the counterpart (not Alexander White) is suggesting now?
          Answer: Counterpart's suggestion is to go to The Duke of York.
          Question: What action Alexander White should do now?
          Answer: Alexander White would suggest The Red Lion as the location to watch the game.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Alexander White likely to say next? Respond in the format `Alexander White -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Alexander White -- "How about The Red Lion? They have great wings.
